articles.title: Press release - Payment services deal: More protection from online fraud and hidden fees
articles.summary: Parliament and Council have struck a deal on a more open and competitive EU payment services sector, with strong defences against fraud and data breaches.Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs Source : © European Union, 2025 - EP
articles.content:
On Thursday morning, Parliament and Council negotiators agreed on the Payment Services Regulation (PSR) and the Third Payment Services Directive (PSD3).

The regulation aims to harmonise payment services and strengthen fraud prevention across the EU. It applies to payment services provided by banks, post-office giro and payment institutions, as well as technical service providers supporting payment services, and in some cases electronic communications providers and online platforms. The directive seeks to ensure fair competition among payment service providers (PSPs), by addressing authorisation and supervisory powers, and to improve access to cash, particularly in remote areas.

Protecting customers from fraud

If a PSP fails to implement appropriate fraud prevention mechanisms, it will be liable for covering customers’ losses. PSPs will be required to check that a payee’s name and unique identifier match. In cases of discrepancies, the PSP will have to refuse the payment order and inform the payer. PSPs will also have to ensure strong customer authentication and conduct a risk assessment.

MEPs confirmed that PSPs have to offer spending limits and blocking measures to reduce the risks of fraud.

If a fraudster initiates or changes a transaction, it will be treated as unauthorised transaction and the PSP will be liable for the full fraudulent amount. Additionally, the receiving PSP will have to freeze any transaction it finds suspicious.

To protect customers from impersonation fraud, where a scammer pretends to be a PSP employee and tricks the customer into approving a payment, the PSP must refund the full amount as long as the customer reports the fraud to the police and informs their PSP.

Online platforms will be liable to PSPs who have reimbursed defrauded customers if they are informed of fraudulent content on their platform and fail to remove it. This builds on and adds to the protection in the Digital Services Act.

In addition, advertisers of financial services must show very large online platforms and search engines that they are legally allowed (or officially exempt) in the relevant country to offer those services, or that they are advertising on behalf of someone who is.

MEPs also ensured that users must have access to human customer support (not only chatbots) and that public resources should be devoted to educating people on how to avoid fraud.

Transparent charges

Customers should be properly informed about all charges prior to the initiation of a payment. They should receive, for example, information about currency conversion charges or any fixed fees for cash withdrawal at automatic telling machines, regardless of who operates them.

Better access to cash

To ensure better access to cash, especially in remote and rural areas, retail stores will be able to provide cash withdrawals of maximum €150 but minimum €100, without the customer having to buy anything.

Improving competition

The negotiators agreed to reduce market barriers for “open banking services” (account information and payment initiation services) and to prevent account-servicing payment service providers (ASPSP) (usually a bank or other financial institution) from discriminating against them. Authorised open banking providers must be able to access payment account data and the legislation includes a list of prohibited obstacles to data access. Furthermore, payment service users will be given a dashboard to monitor and manage the permissions they have given to access their data. Banks will have to provide payment institutions with access to payment accounts on a non-discriminatory basis.

Manufacturers of mobile devices and electronic service providers will have to allow front-end service providers (such as apps or user interfaces) to store and transfer data needed to process payments, on fair, reasonable, and non-discriminatory terms.

Simplified authorisation

The negotiators also agreed to simplify the authorisation procedure for payment institutions. Authorisation should be subject to strong prudential and capital requirements, accurate own-funds calculations, reliable budget forecasts, and harmonised timelines, with initial capital scaled to the provider’s risk level and to the payment services provided. Crypto asset service providers already authorised under Regulation on Markets in Crypto-assets, would be subject to a streamlined procedure while keeping appropriate risk controls and providing only services specified in the application.

Quick dispute resolution

The Parliament’s negotiators insisted on requiring all PSPs to participate in alternative dispute resolution procedures if a consumer chooses it.

Quotes

René Repasi (S&D, DE), rapporteur for the regulation said: "Consumers will benefit from new harmonized rules on the payment services regulation. Mandatory fraud preventive measures will be applied and lead to less payment fraud. Banks have to share more of the burden if they fail to do their part."

"Today’s deal is a win for the Parliament by establishing a liability provision for online platforms where fraud started. In certain cases, they now have to reimburse banks who have reimbursed defrauded customers."

Morten Løkkegaard (Renew, DK), rapporteur for the directive said: “This deal is a significant step toward a more open and resilient single market for payments. By updating outdated rules, we ensure Europe stays competitive in a rapidly evolving financial sector.”



“With today's deal, we have secured better access to cash for citizens across Europe. Besides ATMs, people will now be able to withdraw money in a shop without being forced to make a purchase, ensuring cash remains a genuine and convenient payment option.”

Next steps

The deal needs to be formally adopted by Parliament and Council before it can come into force.

articles.personality_title: EU agrees new rules to fight online payment fraud and improve cash access
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The European Union (EU) is updating its rules for payment services to make online payments safer and fairer. This includes banks, payment companies, and online platforms that help people send or receive money.

**What happened** – On Thursday, EU lawmakers agreed on new regulations called the Payment Services Regulation (PSR) and the Third Payment Services Directive (PSD3). These set stronger rules to stop fraud, require clear information about fees, and improve access to cash, especially in rural areas. Payment service providers (PSPs) must check payments carefully, protect customers from scams, and refund losses if fraud happens.

**Impact** – These new rules make it harder for criminals to steal money online and protect people if something goes wrong. Shops will let customers withdraw cash without buying anything, helping those in places with fewer banks. The rules also make sure payment companies compete fairly and give users control over their payment data.

**What's next step** – The agreement still needs formal approval by the EU Parliament and Council before becoming law. After that, payment services across Europe will follow these new protections and rules.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU’s new payment rules will help protect people from online fraud, make fees clearer, and improve cash access across the continent.
articles.personality_title_fr: L'UE adopte de nouvelles règles pour lutter contre la fraude en ligne et faciliter l'accès à l'argent liquide
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L'Union européenne (UE) met à jour ses règles sur les services de paiement pour rendre les paiements en ligne plus sûrs et plus justes. Cela concerne les banques, les entreprises de paiement et les plateformes en ligne qui aident à envoyer ou recevoir de l'argent.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Jeudi, les législateurs européens ont convenu de nouvelles règles appelées Règlement sur les services de paiement (PSR) et Troisième directive sur les services de paiement (PSD3). Elles renforcent la lutte contre la fraude, exigent la transparence des frais et améliorent l'accès à l'argent liquide, surtout en zones rurales. Les prestataires de services de paiement doivent vérifier les paiements, protéger les clients contre les arnaques et rembourser les pertes en cas de fraude.

**Impact** – Ces nouvelles règles rendent plus difficile le vol d’argent en ligne et protègent les consommateurs en cas de problème. Les magasins permettront aux clients de retirer de l'argent sans achat, aidant ceux vivant loin des banques. Elles garantissent aussi une concurrence équitable et un meilleur contrôle des données de paiement.

**Prochaine étape** – L’accord doit encore être approuvé officiellement par le Parlement et le Conseil de l’UE avant d’entrer en vigueur. Ensuite, tous les services de paiement en Europe appliqueront ces nouvelles protections.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Les nouvelles règles de l’UE protégeront mieux contre la fraude en ligne, clarifieront les frais et faciliteront l’accès à l’argent liquide dans toute l’Europe.
articles.personality_title_es: La UE acuerda nuevas normas para combatir el fraude en pagos en línea y mejorar el acceso al efectivo
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La Unión Europea (UE) está actualizando sus reglas para los servicios de pago para hacer que los pagos en línea sean más seguros y justos. Esto incluye bancos, empresas de pago y plataformas en línea que ayudan a enviar o recibir dinero.

**Qué pasó** – El jueves, los legisladores de la UE acordaron nuevas regulaciones llamadas Reglamento de Servicios de Pago (PSR) y la Tercera Directiva de Servicios de Pago (PSD3). Estas normas fortalecen la prevención del fraude, exigen claridad sobre las tarifas y mejoran el acceso al efectivo, especialmente en áreas rurales. Los proveedores de servicios de pago deben verificar los pagos, proteger a los clientes contra estafas y reembolsar las pérdidas en caso de fraude.

**Impacto** – Estas nuevas reglas dificultan que los delincuentes roben dinero en línea y protegen a las personas si ocurre algún problema. Las tiendas permitirán retirar efectivo sin necesidad de comprar, ayudando a quienes viven en zonas con pocos bancos. También aseguran una competencia justa y que los usuarios controlen sus datos de pago.

**Próximo paso** – El acuerdo necesita la aprobación formal del Parlamento y el Consejo de la UE antes de convertirse en ley. Luego, los servicios de pago en toda Europa seguirán estas nuevas protecciones.

**Resumen en una frase** – Las nuevas reglas de la UE mejorarán la protección contra el fraude en línea, harán más claras las tarifas y facilitarán el acceso al efectivo en todo el continente.

articles.reasoning: The article reports on a significant EU parliamentary initiative to protect minors online by proposing a harmonized minimum age for social media access and banning harmful addictive practices. This policy aims to safeguard children's mental and physical health across the EU, affecting a broad population and addressing urgent societal concerns about digital wellbeing and child protection. articles.personality_title: EU lawmakers propose raising social media age to 16 to protect children online
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Many children and teenagers use social media and online platforms every day. Research shows that some minors develop habits that look like addiction, affecting their mental and physical health. EU countries want stronger rules to keep young people safer online.

**What happened** – On Wednesday, Members of the European Parliament (MEPs) voted mostly in favor of a report asking for new rules. They suggest making 16 the minimum age to use social media, video-sharing sites, and AI chatbots across the EU. Children aged 13 to 16 could still join if their parents agree. The report also calls for banning harmful features like endless scrolling, autoplay videos, and addictive games that can trap young users.

**Impact** – This plan aims to protect millions of children from online dangers by setting one clear age limit for all EU countries. It also pushes platforms to design safer services and stops them from using tricks that make kids spend too much time online. The rules would help parents control their children’s online activity, and hold company leaders responsible if they don’t follow the laws.

**What's next step** – The European Commission will work on tools like an app to verify users’ ages safely and privately. Lawmakers also want new laws to stop unfair advertising and influencer marketing aimed at children. The plan includes banning risky features in online games and new rules for AI tools that affect minors.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU is moving to raise the minimum age for social media use to 16 and ban addictive online features to better protect children’s health and privacy.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les députés européens proposent de fixer l’âge minimum à 16 ans pour accéder aux réseaux sociaux
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – De nombreux enfants et adolescents utilisent les réseaux sociaux et les plateformes en ligne chaque jour. Des recherches montrent que certains mineurs développent des comportements proches de l’addiction, ce qui affecte leur santé mentale et physique. Les pays de l’UE souhaitent des règles plus strictes pour protéger les jeunes en ligne.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Mercredi, les députés européens ont majoritairement voté en faveur d’un rapport demandant de nouvelles règles. Ils proposent de fixer à 16 ans l’âge minimum pour utiliser les réseaux sociaux, les sites de partage de vidéos et les chatbots IA dans toute l’UE. Les enfants de 13 à 16 ans pourraient y accéder avec l’accord de leurs parents. Le rapport demande aussi d’interdire les fonctions nocives comme le défilement infini, la lecture automatique des vidéos et les jeux addictifs qui piègent les jeunes.

**Impact** – Ce plan vise à protéger des millions d’enfants des dangers en ligne en fixant une limite d’âge claire pour tous les pays de l’UE. Il pousse aussi les plateformes à créer des services plus sûrs et à arrêter d’utiliser des astuces qui font passer trop de temps aux enfants en ligne. Ces règles aideraient les parents à mieux contrôler l’activité en ligne de leurs enfants et rendraient les dirigeants responsables en cas de non-respect.

**Prochaine étape** – La Commission européenne va développer des outils comme une application pour vérifier l’âge des utilisateurs de façon sûre et respectueuse de la vie privée. Les législateurs souhaitent aussi de nouvelles lois pour interdire la publicité et le marketing d’influence destinés aux enfants. Le plan inclut l’interdiction des fonctions risquées dans les jeux en ligne et de nouvelles règles pour les outils d’IA qui concernent les mineurs.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – L’UE veut relever à 16 ans l’âge minimum pour accéder aux réseaux sociaux et interdire les fonctions addictives pour mieux protéger la santé et la vie privée des enfants.
articles.personality_title_es: Los eurodiputados proponen subir a 16 años la edad mínima para usar redes sociales y proteger a los niños
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Muchos niños y adolescentes usan redes sociales y plataformas en línea todos los días. Investigaciones muestran que algunos menores desarrollan hábitos similares a la adicción, afectando su salud mental y física. Los países de la UE quieren reglas más fuertes para proteger a los jóvenes en línea.

**Qué pasó** – El miércoles, los miembros del Parlamento Europeo (MEP) votaron mayoritariamente a favor de un informe que pide nuevas normas. Proponen que 16 años sea la edad mínima para usar redes sociales, sitios para compartir videos y chatbots de IA en toda la UE. Los niños de 13 a 16 años podrían acceder con el permiso de sus padres. El informe también pide prohibir funciones dañinas como el desplazamiento infinito, la reproducción automática y juegos adictivos que atrapan a los jóvenes.

**Impacto** – Este plan busca proteger a millones de niños de los peligros en línea fijando un límite de edad claro para todos los países de la UE. También exige que las plataformas diseñen servicios más seguros y dejen de usar trucos que hacen que los niños pasen mucho tiempo en línea. Las reglas ayudarán a los padres a controlar mejor la actividad en línea de sus hijos y harán responsables a los líderes si no cumplen la ley.

**Próximo paso** – La Comisión Europea trabajará en herramientas como una aplicación para verificar la edad de los usuarios de forma segura y privada. Los legisladores quieren nuevas leyes para detener la publicidad y el marketing de influencers dirigidos a niños. El plan incluye prohibir funciones riesgosas en juegos en línea y nuevas reglas para herramientas de IA que afectan a menores.

**Conclusión en una frase** – La UE avanza para subir a 16 años la edad mínima para usar redes sociales y prohibir funciones adictivas para proteger mejor la salud y privacidad de los niños.

articles.title: Peacebuilding Fund hits $1 billion milestone amid funding gap
articles.summary: The United Nations Peacebuilding Fund on Wednesday announced a major milestone, with the approval of more than $1 billion in support to global peacebuilding and conflict-prevention initiatives since 2020.
articles.content:
The multi-donor trust fund is the UN’s primary instrument for supporting countries worldwide who are emerging from – or at risk of – violent conflict. The fund sits alongside the Peacebuilding Commission and the Peacebuilding Support Office.

Tweet URL

The announcement came as the Security Council and the General Assembly passed twin resolutions in support of the UN’s peacebuilding body, providing a blueprint to make it more impactful.

‘Quantum leap’

Making the $1 billion announcement at a press briefing in New York, Peacebuilding Support chief, Elizabeth Spehar, and the Chair of the fund's Advisory Group, Macharia Kamau, said the funding milestone reflects the Secretary-General’s call for a “quantum leap” in financing.

Despite this achievement, the Fund faces a $500 million shortfall toward its $1.5 billion target for the 2020–2026 period, limiting its ability to meet growing demand for its crucial support services from Member States.

The Fund currently supports more than 50 countries, three-quarters of them in Africa.

Joint resolve

Earlier on Wednesday, the Security Council unanimously adopted a resolution in support of the UN’s overall peacebuilding efforts, with the General Assembly adopting the same text a short time later. The coordinated move approving the organization’s peacebuilding architecture first took place in 2005.

The resolution underscores the UN’s ongoing focus on preventing conflict and supporting lasting peace, stressing that real results come when development, human rights and peace and security, work hand in hand.

Ms. Spehar said the timing of the votes and the corresponding announcement of the $1billion funding mark was “very significant”.

For details on the vote and the resolution, go to our meetings coverage page, here.
articles.source: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

The UN's coordinated resolutions and funding efforts demonstrate meaningful progress in peacebuilding, human rights, and conflict prevention on a large scale. The article provides sufficient context about the fund's scope, achievements, and ongoing challenges.
articles.personality_title: UN Peacebuilding Fund reaches $1 billion to support global peace efforts
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The United Nations Peacebuilding Fund helps countries that are recovering from or at risk of violent conflict. It works alongside other UN groups focused on peace and conflict prevention.

**What happened** – On Wednesday, the UN announced that the Peacebuilding Fund has approved over $1 billion since 2020 to support peacebuilding projects worldwide. This milestone was shared during a press briefing in New York by Elizabeth Spehar, head of the Peacebuilding Support Office, and Macharia Kamau, Chair of the Fund’s Advisory Group. At the same time, the UN Security Council and General Assembly passed resolutions to strengthen the UN’s peacebuilding work.

**Impact** – This $1 billion milestone shows strong global support for helping countries avoid or recover from conflict. The Fund now helps more than 50 countries, mostly in Africa. However, there is still a $500 million gap to reach the $1.5 billion goal for 2020–2026. The recent UN resolutions emphasize that lasting peace depends on working together in development, human rights, and security.

**What's next step** – The UN will continue seeking more funding to close the gap and expand support to countries in need. The resolutions passed by the Security Council and General Assembly also provide a plan to make peacebuilding efforts more effective in the coming years.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The UN Peacebuilding Fund has passed $1 billion in support for peace projects worldwide, marking important progress while aiming to raise more funds to help even more countries.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le Fonds pour le maintien de la paix de l’ONU franchit le cap du milliard de dollars pour soutenir les efforts mondiaux de paix
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le Fonds pour le maintien de la paix des Nations Unies aide les pays qui se remettent de conflits violents ou qui risquent d’en connaître. Il travaille avec d’autres groupes de l’ONU dédiés à la paix et à la prévention des conflits.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Mercredi, l’ONU a annoncé que le Fonds avait approuvé plus d’un milliard de dollars depuis 2020 pour soutenir des projets de paix dans le monde. Ce jalon a été présenté lors d’une conférence de presse à New York par Elizabeth Spehar, responsable du Bureau de soutien au maintien de la paix, et Macharia Kamau, président du groupe consultatif du Fonds. En même temps, le Conseil de sécurité et l’Assemblée générale de l’ONU ont adopté des résolutions pour renforcer le travail de maintien de la paix.

**Impact** – Ce cap du milliard de dollars montre un fort soutien mondial pour aider les pays à éviter ou à se remettre des conflits. Le Fonds aide maintenant plus de 50 pays, principalement en Afrique. Cependant, il reste un déficit de 500 millions de dollars pour atteindre l’objectif de 1,5 milliard pour 2020-2026. Les résolutions récentes de l’ONU soulignent que la paix durable dépend d’une collaboration entre développement, droits humains et sécurité.

**Prochaine étape** – L’ONU continuera à chercher des financements pour combler ce déficit et étendre son soutien aux pays dans le besoin. Les résolutions adoptées fournissent aussi un plan pour rendre les efforts de maintien de la paix plus efficaces dans les années à venir.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – Le Fonds pour le maintien de la paix de l’ONU a dépassé un milliard de dollars pour soutenir des projets de paix dans le monde, marquant un progrès important tout en visant à mobiliser plus de fonds pour aider davantage de pays.
articles.personality_title_es: El Fondo de Consolidación de la Paz de la ONU alcanza los 1.000 millones de dólares para apoyar esfuerzos globales de paz
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El Fondo de Consolidación de la Paz de las Naciones Unidas ayuda a países que están saliendo o corren riesgo de sufrir conflictos violentos. Trabaja junto con otros grupos de la ONU que se enfocan en la paz y la prevención de conflictos.

**Qué pasó** – El miércoles, la ONU anunció que el Fondo aprobó más de 1.000 millones de dólares desde 2020 para apoyar proyectos de paz en todo el mundo. Este logro fue compartido en una conferencia de prensa en Nueva York por Elizabeth Spehar, jefa de la Oficina de Apoyo a la Consolidación de la Paz, y Macharia Kamau, presidente del Grupo Asesor del Fondo. Al mismo tiempo, el Consejo de Seguridad y la Asamblea General aprobaron resoluciones para fortalecer el trabajo de la ONU en la consolidación de la paz.

**Impacto** – Este logro de mil millones de dólares muestra un fuerte apoyo global para ayudar a países a evitar o recuperarse de conflictos. El Fondo actualmente apoya a más de 50 países, la mayoría en África. Sin embargo, aún falta medio billón de dólares para alcanzar la meta de 1.500 millones para 2020-2026. Las resoluciones recientes enfatizan que la paz duradera depende de trabajar juntos en desarrollo, derechos humanos y seguridad.

**Próximo paso** – La ONU seguirá buscando más fondos para cerrar la brecha y ampliar el apoyo a los países que lo necesitan. Las resoluciones aprobadas también brindan un plan para hacer que los esfuerzos de consolidación de la paz sean más efectivos en los próximos años.

**Frase clave** – El Fondo de Consolidación de la Paz de la ONU ha superado los 1.000 millones de dólares en apoyo a proyectos de paz en todo el mundo, marcando un progreso importante mientras busca recaudar más fondos para ayudar a más países.

articles.title: Press release - 2025 Sakharov Prize: interviews with laureates’ and finalists’ representatives
articles.summary: The award ceremony for 2025 Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought laureates Andrzej Poczobut and Mzia Amaglobeli will be held on Tuesday 16 December.Committee on Foreign AffairsCommittee on DevelopmentSubcommittee on Human Rights Source : © European Union, 2025 - EP
articles.content:
Journalists can express their interest in conducting interviews with the representatives of the Sakharov Prize laureates by registering via this EU survey link by Friday 5 December at 18.00 CET at the latest. Consecutive interpretation in English will be provided.



Read more about the European Parliament’s 2025 Sakharov Prize here.



The main representative for Andrzej Poczobut, from Belarus, will be his daughter Jana Poczobut who will be accompanied by Anna Kietlińska, President of the Podlaskie Branch of the "Polish Community" Association.



For Mzia Amaglobeli, from Georgia, the representatives attending the award ceremony will be Irma Dimitradze, journalist at Gazeti Batumelebi, and Khatuna Jinjikhadze, Deputy Director of the Civil Society Foundation in Georgia. They will be accompanied by Caoilfhionn Gallagher KC, international lawyer.



Representatives of the other finalists for the 2025 Sakharov Prize will also be in Strasbourg during the award ceremony week and available for interviews:



- Marta Lorenzo, Director of the UNRWA Representative Office for Europe;



- Nasser Abu Bakr, President of the Palestinian Journalists Syndicate;



- Dr Younis Al-Khatib, President of the Palestinian Red Crescent Society (PRCS); and



- representatives of Serbian students.



Please note that making a request does not guarantee you will be granted an interview.



You will receive confirmation of whether you have secured an interview slot, or not, on Wednesday 10 December at the latest.



Interviews will take place on Monday 15 December in the afternoon, Tuesday 16 December in the afternoon, Wednesday 17 December in the morning.



Media seminar



Journalists can also take part in a hybrid media seminar with this year’s Sakharov Prize laureate representatives and finalists, and with MEPs. The event will take place on Tuesday 16 December, from 9.00 to 11.15.



For more information you will find the programme here. To register to attend in person or to get the link to Interactio, please contact: media-seminars@europarl.europa.eu.



Contacts for the interviews

Brussels-based correspondents - Eliana Capretti - eliana.capretti@europarl.europa.eu - +32 473 33 25 82

Journalists from the member states and other countries - Eva Egido - eva.egido@europarl.europa.eu - + 32 470 74 31 14

articles.personality_title: 2025 Sakharov Prize ceremony to honor human rights defenders
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The Sakharov Prize is an award given by the European Parliament to people who defend freedom of thought and human rights around the world. Every year, individuals or groups who have made important contributions to these causes are recognized.

**What happened** – The 2025 Sakharov Prize will be awarded on Tuesday, December 16, to Andrzej Poczobut from Belarus and Mzia Amaglobeli from Georgia. Their representatives, including family members and experts, will attend the ceremony in Strasbourg, France.
